brown.tracingplane.atomlayer

Class Lexicographic

  • java.lang.Object
    • brown.tracingplane.atomlayer.Lexicographic

  • public class Lexicographic
extends java.lang.Object

    This class has static methods for lexicographically comparing bytes. Lexicographic comparison compares the unsigned byte representations starting from the left-most bit. It is like alphabetical comparison but for bytes. For example, consider the following:

    • a = 0000 0001
    • b = 1000 0010 0010 0000
    • c = 0000 0000 0000 1111

    The lexicographic ordering for this example is c < a < b.

    • Method Detail

      • compare

        public static int compare(byte a,
                          byte b)
        Perform lexicographical (ie, unsigned) comparison on two bytes
        Parameters:
        a - a byte. this function uses the unsigned value of a, so if a < 0, the function compares a + 256.
        b - a byte. this function uses the unsigned value of b, so if b < 0, the function compares b + 256.
        Returns:
        compares the unsigned values of a and b, returning a negative integer if a < b, 0 if a == b, or a positive integer if a > b.

      • compare

        public static int compare(byte[] a,
                          byte[] b)
        Performs lexicographical comparison on two byte arrays, starting with index 0.
        Parameters:
        a - an array of bytes
        b - an array of bytes
        Returns:
        the lexicographical comparison of a and b: a negative integer if a < b, 0 if a == b, or a positive integer if a > b.

      • compare

        public static int compare(java.nio.ByteBuffer a,
                          java.nio.ByteBuffer b)
        Performs lexicographical comparison on two ByteBuffers, starting with index 0. This method uses absolute indexes to compare a and b, and does not change their position or limit.
        Parameters:
        a - an array of bytes
        b - an array of bytes
        Returns:
        the lexicographical comparison of a and b: a negative integer if a < b, 0 if a == b, or a positive integer if a > b.

      • merge

        public static java.util.List<java.nio.ByteBuffer> merge(java.util.List<java.nio.ByteBuffer> a,
                                                        java.util.List<java.nio.ByteBuffer> b)

        Lexicographically merges the two provided lists of ByteBuffers. This method does not sort a, or b, or the returned list.

        If the merge encounters identical values (e.g., the next value of a == the next value of b), then both a and b are advanced, and the value is only include once. For example: 

         a = [ 00000100, 00001000, 00000001 ];                               // [4, 8, 1]
 b = [ 00000010, 00001000, 00000011 ];                               // [2, 8, 3]
 merge(a, b) = [ 00000010, 00000100, 00001000, 00000001, 00000011 ]; // [2, 4, 8, 1, 3]
        Parameters:
        a - a list of bytebuffers, possibly null
        b - a list of bytebuffers, possibly null
        Returns:
        a and b, lexicographically merged

      • merge

        @SafeVarargs
public static java.util.Iterator<java.nio.ByteBuffer> merge(java.util.Iterator<java.nio.ByteBuffer> a,
                                                                         java.util.Iterator<java.nio.ByteBuffer> b,
                                                                         java.util.Iterator<java.nio.ByteBuffer>... moreIterators)

        Takes two or more iterators as input and creates a MergeIterator that produces values in lexicographic order as would be produced by merge(List, List)

        If the merge encounters identical values (e.g., the next value of a == the next value of b), then both a and b are advanced, and the value is only include once. For example: 

         a = [ 00000100, 00001000, 00000001 ];                               // [4, 8, 1]
 b = [ 00000010, 00001000, 00000011 ];                               // [2, 8, 3]
 merge(a, b) = [ 00000010, 00000100, 00001000, 00000001, 00000011 ]; // [2, 4, 8, 1, 3]
        Parameters:
        a - an iterator of bytebuffers, possibly null, possibly exhausted
        b - an iterator of bytebuffers, possibly null, possibly exhausted
        moreIterators - zero or more iterators of bytebuffers, possibly null, possibly exhausted
        Returns:
        an iterator that produces elements from the input iterators, merged lexicographically
